frameDefinitions: This frame concerns the appointment of a New_leader or removal from office of an Old_leader.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
These words refer to an Agent joining Parts to form a Whole.
A Communicator communicates a judgment of an Evaluee to an Addressee.
A Protester (or Protesters) expresses a strong opinion either in support of or against an Issue, or the Action(s) of a Side which relate to the Issue.
A Communicator publically communicates some difficult-to-express Content which they (or a social group of which they are a member) have had for some time.
frameExamples: On March 17 , Mamedov <t>appointed</t> Rakhim Gasiyev as Defence Minister .
I <t>commended</t> his handling of the crisis.
Several hundred Tibetans, already worried by inflation, took to the streets to <t>protest</t> at the new measures.
Those grievances can be <t>aired</t> during Board meetings. CNI
listRoleDefinitions: The Selector (most commonly a group of people) is responsible for a change in leadership.  Typically, it occurs as the External Argument of verbs.

With words denoting removal (or attempted removal) from office of a leader, the <fen>Old_leader</fen> is typically the direct object of verbs, or occurs in a PP Complement with noun targets, frequently headed by the preposition <ment>against</ment>.
With words denoting appointment to a position, the <fen>New_leader</fen> is typically the object of verbs.

Frequently the <fen>Old_leader</fen> or <fen>New_leader</fen> is referred to only by his/her role. However, the <fen>Role</fen> can be expressed separately from the leader, usually as either a secondary predicate or in a PP Complement.
The role <fen>Old_order</fen> identifies the political order that existed before the change of leadership occurs.
The <fen>Function</fen> is the purpose the <fen>New_leader</fen> will fufill.
A group of individuals who are elected or appointed to perform some function of governance.
When the change takes place.
Where the change takes place.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:

In causative uses of these verbs there is an <fen>Agent</fen> responsible for amalgamating the <fen>Parts</fen>. The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally the External Argument (or the object of a PP-by in passives).
This  role identifies <fen>Whole</fen> as the entity resulting from combination of <fen>Parts</fen>.  When overtly expressed, it is usually a PP Complement (often headed by into).
This role identifies the <fen>Parts</fen> entities being combined, and is often expressed in a single plural NP, usually the direct object of a verb.
This role identifies the first of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. It  is most often the NP-Object of a verb.
This role identifies the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. It is usually a PP Complement.
The time at which the amalgamation occurs.
The location that the event occurs.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey his or her evaluation of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> to another person.
<fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract setting in which the evaluation is conveyed.
<fen>Topic</fen> identifies the entity to which the proposition or propositions conveyed relate.
A judgment is made about the <fen>Evaluee</fen>  With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the <fen>Communicator</fen>'s judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP.
When the communication of the judgment takes place.
Where the communication of the judgment takes place.
The individual (or individuals) who holds an opinion on an Issue or Side.
The matter, usually concerning a course of action, which the <fen>Protester</fen> has an positive or negative opinion about.
The party or individual (generally associated with a particular position on an <fen>Issue</fen>) that the <fen>Protester</fen> sides with.
An action taken by a Side or a view that the Side takes on an issue which the <fen>Protester</fen> either supports or opposes.
The time period during which the Protesters express their opinions.
The location where the <fen>Protester</fen> takes <fen>Side</fen>s on an <fen>Issue</fen> .
The <fen>Communicator</fen> is the person who expresses the <fen>Content</fen> (whether spoken or written).
The attitude or feeling that the <fen>Communicator</fen> had not previously expressed.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the observable action or product of the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Content</fen> is communicated.
The role specifies the place where the communication takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The voters</fex> elected Blair.
The students overthrew <fex>the president</fex>.
The president appoints <fex>the prime minister</fex>.
The board of directors appointed Ashton <fex>Acting President</fex>.
The rebels overthrew <fex>the dictatorship</fex>.
His district elected her  <fex>to Congress</fex> three times.
The <fex>2000</fex> coup against the dictator was led by former president Smith.
The crew mutinied <fex>out in the middle of the Atlantic</fex>, the scoundrels.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>The chef</fex> combined the ingredients.
Chuck merged the corpora <fex>into a database</fex>.
Chuck merged <fex>the corpora</fex> into a database.
The workmen joined <fex>the annex</fex> to the main building.
The workkmen joined the annex <fex>to the main building</fex>.
<fex>Jon</fex> belittled Madie to her colleagues.
Jon belittled Madie <fex>over the telephone</fex>.
Jon criticized Madie <fex>about her managerial style</fex>.
Jon belittled <fex>Madie</fex> to her colleagues.
She viewed him with a critical <fex>gaze</fex>.
Jon extolled Madie <fex>for her efforts</fex>.
He received critical acclaim <fex>last week</fex>.
He was belittled by his long-time friend <fex>in front of his family</fex>.
On 8 May a <fex>student</fex> demonstration was attended by a large number of workers.
Hundreds gathered this afternoon to demonsrate <fex>for women's rights</fex>.
Violent protests <fex>against the government</fex> are sure to break out.
Several hundred Tibetans, already worried by inflation, took to the streets to protest <fex>at the new measures</fex>.
<fex>Reagan</fex> gave voice to the innate patriotism of the American people.
Members aired <fex>their grievances</fex> and resented the way higher education was being dealt with.
I do not especially espouse the ideas articulated by Diana Plesa <fex>in her article</fex>.
Sometimes, children may <fex>later</fex> put into words a memory from early life, but not customarily.
John Ryan voiced concerns <fex>in Parliament</fex> about the suggestion that somehow the inquiry was not independent.
